blog.title: How to learn React
blog.content:
React Tutorial in Hindi


In this tutorial, I will be teaching you ReactJS from starting to end. But before deep-diving into the coding part, let me give you a quick introduction of ReactJS and why you should use it.


Introduction :


ReactJS is a JavaScript library originally developed by Facebook that helps in building highly engaging single-page web apps. Many developers call ReactJS a framework instead of a JS library because it is directly comparable with AngularJS. The reason why ReactJS has gained so much popularity in the past years is its simplicity. You need minimal knowledge of JavaScript and HTML. Another thing that helps ReactJS stand out is breaking down the complex UI into simpler components. Today, Facebook’s codebase is containing more than 20,000 React components. Big tech giants such as PayPal, Instagram, Uber, WhatsApp, Yahoo, etc., are using ReactJS to solve their complex UI problems.  


So, we’ve talked enough about the awesomeness of ReactJS. It’s time to get started with the coding part. We will be creating a To-Dos list project with ReactJS. I will be covering the most fundamental aspects & techniques of ReactJS that will help you to create more complex projects in the future.


 


 


Installation :


Node & NPM Installation :


  1. To install ReactJS on your system, you first need to install NodeJS and npm. NodeJS is the platform needed for ReactJS, and npm, which stands for Node Package Manager, will help you to install and manage various JS packages. The good news is that you don’t need to install NodeJS and npm separately. Once you install NodeJS, npm will be automatically installed on your system.
  2. Click here, and you’ll be redirected to the official download page of NodeJS. Download the latest version of NodeJS for your operating system.
  3. Install the NodeJS on your system like any other piece of software.
  4. Once the installation is done, open the Windows PowerShell and type node -v. If the version number is displayed, then NodeJS is successfully installed on your system. Similarly, you can check for npm by typing :

npm -v

Copy


Setting Up The Development Environment :


  1. After installing NodeJS and npm, it’s time to select the directory where you want to save your React app.
  2. Once you’ve done that, open the directory in file explorer and press SHIFT+ Right-click. Then click on Open PowerShell Window here.
  3. After opening the PowerShell window, type :

npx create-react-app todos-list

Copy


Todos-list is the name of our app, and as soon as you execute the above command, the creation of react app will be started, as shown in the below image.



 


 


  1. Wait until you see a success message, as shown in the below image


  1. After completing the installation process, a folder named TODOS-LIST will be created on your system. Open that folder in VS Code.

If VS Code is not installed on your system, click here to read a step-by-step installation guide of VS Code.


Basic Folder Structure :


On opening your React app in VS code, you will see a bunch of files. Here is a quick explanation of some important files you’ll be interacting with :


  1. Public/index.html: This is the main and only HTML file of our React app. This is the page that will be loaded on starting the application.
  2. src/index.js: This is the JavaScript file corresponding to the index.html file, and it is responsible for routing to React components.
  3. src/App.js: App.js is the main component of any React app.
  4. src/App.css: This file is responsible for injecting styling in the React app.

Since I've given you an idea of some important files in our React app, it's time to start the development server for our React app. To start the development server, open the inbuilt terminal of VS Code and type the below command :


npm start

Copy


Once the above command is successfully executed, open your browser and head over to http://localhost:3000. You will see the following screen :



Congratulate yourself for starting your React app for the very first time. With this, we're all set with the setup part, and now we will start developing our To-dos list app.


 


 


Integrating Bootstrap Into Our React App :


I will be using Bootstrap in our React app so that we can focus only on the React app and do not waste our time in writing CSS. To integrate Bootstrap, we need to include the link of CSS and JavaScript provided by the official website of Boostrap.


JavaScript :


<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.0.0-beta3/dist/js/bootstrap.bundle.min.js" 
  integrity="sha384-JEW9xMcG8R+pH31jmWH6WWP0WintQrMb4s7ZOdauHnUtxwoG2vI5DkLtS3qm9Ekf" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>

Copy


Copy and paste the above code in the public/index.html file at the end of the <body> tag.


CSS :


<link href="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/bootstrap@5.0.0-beta3/dist/css/bootstrap.min.css" rel="stylesheet"
      integrity="sha384-eOJMYsd53ii+scO/bJGFsiCZc+5NDVN2yr8+0RDqr0Ql0h+rP48ckxlpbzKgwra6" crossorigin="anonymous">

Copy


Copy-paste the above stylesheet <link> into your <head> of public/index.html file. With this, we've successfully integrated Bootstrap into our React app, and now we will start creating the components for our React app.


Components In React :


  • Any React app remains divided into several components.
  • Components are nothing but reusable JavaScript functions.
  • Complex UIs can be created easily by breaking them into several components.
  • Every component in React works independently.
  • Even if the components do not depend on each other, they merge inside a parent component to produce the final UI.

Need Of Components :


You might be thinking, why do we need components? Why can't we simply write all the code of a webpage inside a single file? Well! This is what we were doing before React. Before React, developers used to follow the traditional DOM structure to create web pages. But, there are some problems with the traditional approach, like lack of reusability of code or if any mistake is found, it is a challenging task to update because the developer needs to search manually and then update accordingly. But, this is not the case with React, if any mistake is found, we can easily update the code of a particular component.


So, now we're aware of the concept and need of components in React. So, let's get started with creating the first component for our React app.


Creating Header Component :


The first component that we will be creating is the header component. This component will contain the navigation bar of our React app. We will create all the components inside a single directory. So, create a folder named MyComponents inside the src folder. Create a new file named Header.js inside the MyComponents folder. Header.js is the file that will contain all the code for the Header component. Now, we will create a functional-based component in the Header.js.


Syntax of React functional-based component :


import React from 'react'

export default function Header() {
    return (
     //Statements that we want to return
    )
}

Copy


 


 


In the above code, first, we've imported React from the react module, and then we can return our desired piece of code inside the Header function. As I mentioned earlier, the Header component of our app will contain a navigation bar, so we will be returning the code of the navigation bar inside the Header function. Below is the code of the navigation bar :


 <nav className="navbar navbar-expand-lg navbar-light bg-light">
        <div className="container-fluid">
          <a className="navbar-brand" href="#">{props.title}</a>
          <button className="navbar-toggler" type="button" data-bs-toggle="collapse" data-bs-target="#navbarSupportedContent" aria-controls="navbarSupportedContent" 
          aria-expanded="false" aria-label="Toggle navigation">
            <span className="navbar-toggler-icon"></span>
          </button>
          <div className="collapse navbar-collapse" id="navbarSupportedContent">
            <ul className="navbar-nav me-auto mb-2 mb-lg-0">
              <li className="nav-item">
                <a className="nav-link active" aria-current="page" href="#">Home</a>
              </li>
              <li className="nav-item">
                <a className="nav-link" href="#">About</a>
              </li>
              
      
            </ul>
            <form className="d-flex">
              <input className="form-control me-2" type="search" placeholder="Search" aria-label="Search" />
              <button className="btn btn-outline-success" type="submit">Search</button>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </nav>

Copy


Copy-paste the above code inside the return statement of the Header function. Your final code will look like this :


import React from 'react'

export default function Header(props) {
    return (
        <nav className="navbar navbar-expand-lg navbar-light bg-light">
        <div className="container-fluid">
          <a className="navbar-brand" href="#">{props.title}</a>
          <button className="navbar-toggler" type="button" data-bs-toggle="collapse" data-bs-target="#navbarSupportedContent" aria-controls="navbarSupportedContent" 
          aria-expanded="false" aria-label="Toggle navigation">
            <span className="navbar-toggler-icon"></span>
          </button>
          <div className="collapse navbar-collapse" id="navbarSupportedContent">
            <ul className="navbar-nav me-auto mb-2 mb-lg-0">
              <li className="nav-item">
                <a className="nav-link active" aria-current="page" href="#">Home</a>
              </li>
              <li className="nav-item">
                <a className="nav-link" href="#">About</a>
              </li>
              
            </ul>
            <form className="d-flex">
              <input className="form-control me-2" type="search" placeholder="Search" aria-label="Search" />
              <button className="btn btn-outline-success" type="submit">Search</button>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </nav>
    )
}

Copy


In the above code, you can see that we've passed the props parameter to the header function. Props are nothing but Javascript objects that are passed from the parent component to the child component. In the third line of the Header function, you can see that we've written {props.title}, which means that we will be passing the title object from the App.js to Header.js.


 


 


Now, we need to import the Header component inside the App.js file. As I mentioned above, every React component is merged in the main component, i.e., App.js. So, open the src/App.js file and type the following code to import the header component :


import Header from './MyComponents/Header'

Copy


Now, type the following code in the App.js file to return the header component on the main page.


function App() {
  return (
    <>
  <Header title="ToDos List"/>
    </>
  );
}

Copy


In the above code, you can see that we've passed title= "ToDo List", which will be rendered inside the Header function. Your final code of App.js will look like this :


import './App.css';
import Header from './MyComponents/Header'

function App() {
  return (
    <>
    <Header title="ToDos List"/>
    </>
  );
}

export default App;

Copy


This is all we need to do to return the Header component on the main page. Now, head over to the local development server, and your screen will look like this :



 


 


Default Props :


When we talked about props, I told you that the parent component passes the attributes to the child component. We've also seen that how we passed title from the parent to Header component. But, what will happen if the parent component does not pass any attribute to the child component? In such cases, we will see undefined in the places of the attributes not sent by the parent component. Nobody wants to display undefined on the app because it will show the user that our app is suspicious or not working correctly. To deal with such cases, React comes with the concept of Default Props.


As the name suggests, Default Props will set the default values for the props attributes if the parent component does not send the value. Let's see how it's done :


Header.defaultProps={
  title: "Your title here"
}

Copy


Type the above code at the end of the Header.js file. In the above code, we've set the default value of the title attribute as "Your title here". So, if the parent component does not pass the value of the title attribute, then "Your title here" will be displayed to the user. Open the App.js and do not pass any value for the title attribute as shown in the below code :


import './App.css';
import Header from './MyComponents/Header'

function App() {
  return (
    <>
    <Header/>
    </>
  );
}

export default App;

Copy


Output :



In the above image, it is clearly visible that "Your title here" is rendered when we've not passed any value for the title attribute from the parent component. So, that's how you can easily set the default values for the props attributes and increase the reusability of your code.


 


 


Creating Todo and TodoItem Components:


We're done with the development of our Header component. Now, it's time to create two more components :


  1. Todo Component: This component will be responsible for keeping track of all the items included inside the todos list.
  2. TodoItem: This component will be responsible for keeping track of the individual todo items.

Now, we will create a Todo list in the parent component, and then we will pass the list to Todos Component. So, first of all, open the App.js file and type the below code :


import './App.css';
import Header from './MyComponents/Header'
import {Todos} from './MyComponents/Todos'
import {TodoItem} from './MyComponents/TodoItem'

function App() {
  let todos =[
    {
      sno :1,
      Title : "Go to the market",
      Desc : "You need to go to the market to buy some fresh vegetables"
    },
    {
      sno :2,
      Title : "Go to the mall",
      Desc : "You need to go to the mall to buy some gucci shoes"
    },
    {
      sno :3,
      Title : "Go to the voting center",
      Desc : "You need to go to the voting center to vote"
    }
  ]
  return (
    <>
    <Header title="ToDos List"/>
    <Todos todos = {todos} />

    </>
  );
}
export default App;

Copy


In the above code, you can see that we've created a Javascript object named todos containing the list of items in the todos list. After this, we've passed the todos object to the Todos component. Now, we need to create our Todo component. So, create a new file named Todos.js in the MyComponents directory. Type the below code in the Todos.js :


import React from 'react'
import {TodoItem} from "./TodoItem";

export const Todos = (props) => {
    return (
        <div className="container">
        <h3 className="text-center my-3"> Todos List : </h3>
        {props.todos.map((todo)=>{
            return <TodoItem todo={todo}/>
        })}
        
        </div>
    )
}

Copy


 


 


Now, we need to create our third component that is TodoItem. So, create a new file named TodoItem.js in the MyComponents directory. Type the below code in the TodoItem.js file :


import React from 'react'

export const TodoItem = ({todo, onDelete}) => {
    return (
        <div>
        <h4>{todo.Title}</h4>
        <p>{todo.Desc}</p>
        </div>
    )  
}

Copy


With this, we're all set to display all the items of our todo list on the main. So, restart and development and you will see the below screen :



In the above image, you can clearly see that all the items of our todo list are displayed successfully. Now, we will create buttons to add and delete the items from the todo list.


Creating Delete Button :


To create the delete button, we will use the state hooks in React. So, open the App.js file and import state hooks by adding the below import statement :


import React, {useState} from 'react';

Copy


Type the below code in the App.js file :


import './App.css';
import Header from './MyComponents/Header'
...import statements

function App() {

  const onDelete=(todo)=>{
    setTodos(todos.filter((e)=>{
      return e!==todo;

    }));
  }
 
  const [todos, setTodos] = useState([ 
  
    {
      sno :1,
      Title : "Go to the market",
      Desc : "You need to go to the market to buy some fresh vegetables"
    },
    {
      sno :2,
      Title : "Go to the mall",
      Desc : "You need to go to the mall to buy some gucci shoes"
    },
    {
      sno :3,
      Title : "Go to the voting center",
      Desc : "You need to go to the voting center to vote"
    },

  ]);
  return (
    <>
    <Header title="ToDos List"/>
    <Todos todos = {todos} onDelete={onDelete}/>
    </>
  );
}
export default App;

Copy


 


 


In the above code, we've created an onDelete function which will be called once the user clicks on the delete button. Inside the return function, we've passed the onDelete attribute to the Todos component. Now, open the todos.js file and type the below command :


... import statements

export const Todos = (props) => {
    return (
        <div className="container">
        <h3 className="text-center my-3"> Todos List : </h3>
        {props.todos.length===0? " No Todos to display" :
        props.todos.map((todo)=>{
            return <TodoItem todo={todo} key={todo.sno}onDelete={props.onDelete}/>
        })
    }
        </div>

    )
}

Copy


In the above code, we're checking the length of the todos, so if the user deletes all the todo items(length =0) then "No Todos to display" will be shown to the user. Open the TodoItem.js fie and type the below command :


import React from 'react'
export const TodoItem = ({todo, onDelete}) => {
    return (
        <div>
        <h4>{todo.Title}</h4>
        <p>{todo.Desc}</p>
        <button className="btn btn-sm btn-danger" onClick={()=>{onDelete(todo)}}>
            Delete</button>
        </div>
    )  
}

Copy


In the above code, we've created a Delete button, which will call the onDelete function once the user clicks on it and the particular todo item will be removed from the list. With this, we're done with the development of the Delete button. Restart the development server and you will notice that the delete button is working as shown in the below animation :



 


 


Fetching Todo Items From LocalStorage :


Open the App.js and type the below code :


import './App.css';
import Header from "./MyComponents/Header";
import { Todos } from "./MyComponents/Todos";
import { Footer } from "./MyComponents/Footer";
import { AddTodo } from "./MyComponents/AddTodo";
import { About } from "./MyComponents/About";
import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react';
import {
  BrowserRouter as Router,
  Switch,
  Route
} from "react-router-dom";

function App() {
  let initTodo;
  if (localStorage.getItem("todos") === null) {
    initTodo = [];
  }
  else {
    initTodo = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem("todos"));
  }


  const onDelete = (todo) => {
    console.log("I am ondelete of todo", todo);
    // Deleting this way in react does not work
    // let index = todos.indexOf(todo);
    // todos.splice(index, 1);

    setTodos(todos.filter((e) => {
      return e !== todo;
    }));
    console.log("deleted", todos)
    localStorage.setItem("todos", JSON.stringify(todos));
  }

  const addTodo = (title, desc) => {
    console.log("I am adding this todo", title, desc)
    let sno;
    if (todos.length === 0) {
      sno = 0;
    }
    else {
      sno = todos[todos.length - 1].sno + 1;
    }
    const myTodo = {
      sno: sno,
      title: title,
      desc: desc,
    }
    setTodos([...todos, myTodo]);
    console.log(myTodo);
  }

  const [todos, setTodos] = useState(initTodo);
  useEffect(() => {
    localStorage.setItem("todos", JSON.stringify(todos));
  }, [todos])

  return ( 
    <> 
    <Router>
      <Header title="My Todos List" searchBar={false} /> 
      <Switch>
          <Route exact path="/" render={()=>{
            return(
            <>
            <AddTodo addTodo={addTodo} />
            <Todos todos={todos} onDelete={onDelete} /> 
            </>)
          }}> 
          </Route>
          <Route exact path="/about">
            <About />
          </Route> 
        </Switch> 
      <Footer />
    </Router>
    </>
  );
}

export default App;

Copy


Now, create a new file named AddTodo.js file. This is the corresponding javascript file for adding components to the todo list. Type the below code :


import React, { useState } from 'react';

export const AddTodo = ({ addTodo }) => {
    const [title, setTitle] = useState("");
    const [desc, setDesc] = useState("");


    const submit = (e) => {
        e.preventDefault();
        if (!title || !desc) {
            alert("Title or Description cannot be blank");
        }
        else {
            addTodo(title, desc);
            setTitle("");
            setDesc("");
        }
    }
    return (
        <div className="container my-3">
            <h3>Add a Todo</h3>
            <form onSubmit={submit}>
                <div className="mb-3">
                    <label htmlFor="title" className="form-label">Todo Title</label>
                    <input type="text" value={title} onChange={(e) => setTitle(e.target.value)} className="form-control" id="title" aria-describedby="emailHelp" />

                </div>
                <div className="mb-3">
                    <label htmlFor="desc" className="form-label">Todo Description</label>
                    <input type="text" value={desc} onChange={(e) => setDesc(e.target.value)} className="form-control" id="desc" />
                </div>
                <button type="submit" className="btn btn-sm btn-success">Add Todo</button>
            </form>
        </div>
    )
}

Copy


 


 


Type the below code in the TodoItem.js file :


import React from 'react'

export const TodoItem = ({todo, onDelete}) => {
    return (
        <>
        <div>
           <h4>{todo.title}</h4>
           <p>{todo.desc}</p>
           <button className="btn btn-sm btn-danger" onClick={()=>{onDelete(todo)}}>Delete</button> 
        </div>
        <hr/> 
        </>
    )
}

Copy


Type the below code in the todos.js file :


import React from 'react'
import {TodoItem} from "./TodoItem";

export const Todos = (props) => {
    let myStyle = {
        minHeight: "70vh",
        margin: "40px auto"
    }
    return (
        <div className="container" style={myStyle}>
            <h3 className="my-3">Todos List</h3>
            {props.todos.length===0? "No Todos to display":  
            props.todos.map((todo)=>{
                console.log(todo.sno);
                return (<TodoItem todo={todo} key={todo.sno} onDelete={props.onDelete}/>   
                )
            })
              } 
        </div>
    )
}

Copy


With this, we've successfully completed the development of our todos list React app. Restart the development server and you will see that you can easily add and delete the items from the todo list. You can also find the same in the below animation :
